author: By Eric Guth and Jennifer Kingsley
title: Abundance, Exploitation, Recovery: A Portrait of South Georgia
description: A series of ecological initiatives, including the eradication of several invasive species, has dramatically revived the life and landscape of this remote sub-Antarctic island.
content: Sally Poncet first came to South Georgia in 1977. Back then, she said, the sub-Antarctic island was as gorgeous as it is today: A spine of mountains, some 100 miles long, defines the terrain; glaciers drape down from the peaks, with verdant slopes running up to meet them; glistening beaches wrap around the shoreline. But in those days, Ms. Poncet recalled, the island had an empty feel to it. “You felt a lack,” she explained. “It wasn’t alive like you knew it could be.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Attend a Talk With ‘the Challah Prince’
description: Idan Chabasov, known for his baroque creations on Instagram, will discuss and demonstrate challah-making at the Streicker Center.
content: By the time Idan Chabasov takes center stage at Temple Emanu-El’s Streicker Center, Passover will have ended and it will be time to talk of bread again. Mr. Chabasov, whose background is Sephardic, only came to appreciate the traditional braided loaf as an adult, in Berlin. He is now known as the “challah prince” thanks to his baroque creations posted on Instagram. On Monday at 6 p.m. he will discuss and demonstrate challah making with Shannon Sarna, a cookbook author. Coming up at the Streicker Center on the Upper East Side on May 12, the topic will be the Zabar family and stores.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser and Nicholas Fandos
title: Ex-New York Lt. Gov. Previews Bribery Defense: ‘No Personal Benefits’
description: The case against Brian Benjamin, who resigned as New York’s second-in-command last week, may hinge on whether political contributions in this case constituted a bribe.
content: A federal prosecutor said on Monday that the government had issued more than 160 subpoenas for financial, phone and other records as part of its investigation into New York’s former lieutenant governor, Brian A. Benjamin, who resigned last week after being charged with bribery and fraud.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Goldstein
title: Florida Rejects Math Textbooks, Citing ‘Prohibited Topics’
description: Officials said they objected to the inclusion of social-emotional learning and critical race theory in the books but did not share information on the specific content.
content: Florida has rejected 42 of 132 math textbooks proposed for use in public school classrooms because they “incorporate prohibited topics or unsolicited strategies” including social-emotional learning and critical race theory, according to the state’s Department of Education.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Russia Launches Assault in Eastern Ukraine
description: Plus China’s lockdowns slow its economy and France’s candidates vie for undecided voters.
content: The much-dreaded Russian offensive in eastern Ukraine has begun, a top Ukrainian security official said on Monday. Russian forces had broken through the 300-mile front line, which runs along the Donbas and Kharkiv regions, at two separate points.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Arraf
title: A Russian strike hits Lviv, a city relatively untouched by violence.
description: Hundreds of thousands of displaced people from other parts of Ukraine have fled to, or through, Lviv to escape the fighting. Then it landed on their doorstep.
content: LVIV, Ukraine — Russian missiles struck Lviv on Monday, killing at least seven people in the first reported deaths of the war in the western city, where hundreds of thousands of displaced people have fled to escape the fierce fighting in other parts of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg
title: An Older Marathoner Piles Up the Goals
description: In 2019, Mariko Yugeta became the first woman older than 60 to finish a marathon in less than three hours. In the Boston Marathon, she tried to do it again.
content: BOSTON — The day before the Boston Marathon, two marathon giants met off Boylston Street.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annabelle Williams
title: Kathryn Hays, Soap Star for Nearly 40 Years, Dies at 87
description: A string of TV credits, including a turn on “Star Trek,” led to an enduring role on “As the World Turns,” in which her character matured as Ms. Hays aged.
content: Kathryn Hays, an actress who had a brief yet memorable turn in the “Star Trek” television series of the 1960s but who found enduring appeal as a stalwart soap opera star on “As the World Turns” for almost four decades, died on March 25 in Fairfield, Conn. She was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: ‘Frontline’ Review: Why the Climate Changed but We Didn’t
description: “The Power of Big Oil” examines a dispiriting, well-financed history of denialism and inaction.
content: PBS’s investigative public-affairs program “Frontline” specializes in reminding us of things we would rather forget. On Tuesday, it begins a three-part dive into climate change, that potential species-killer that has taken a back seat recently to more traditional scourges like disease and war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lananh Nguyen
title: Bank of America is confident in the economy even as its profits declined.
description: The bank reported lower quarterly profits, but it expects to earn significantly more money later this year from rising interest rates.
content: Bank of America joined its peers in reporting lower profits for the first three months of the year but is keeping its optimistic economic outlook even as other lending giants have turned more cautious.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut and Monique Jaques
title: The Female Soccer Players Challenging France’s Hijab Ban
description: France’s soccer federation forbids hijab-wearing women from competing in soccer games, even though FIFA allows them. A collective of Muslim players is fighting what it considers a discriminatory rule.
content: SARCELLES, France — Every time Mama Diakité heads to a soccer game, her stomach is in knots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: In 1972, only 8 women ran the race. Today, 12,100 are running.
description: Women had been banned from the Boston Marathon for 76 years before a change 50 years ago.
content: For 76 years, men were the only athletes permitted to have their “vital statistics” — their race times — recorded in the running of the Boston Marathon. Women were prohibited from running the route because race organizers considered them “physiologically incapable.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Turner
title: ‘See You Then’ Review: The More Things Stay the Same
description: Former lovers reconnect, litigating the past and present, in this drama from Mari Walker.
content: The golden glow that halos around the two former lovers reconnecting in “See You Then” is tinged with melancholy. More than a decade has passed since the sudden breakup of Kris (Pooya Mohseni) and Naomi (Lynn Chen). Some things have changed, some things stayed the same. That such an aphorism is easily applied to any number of “Before Sunrise”-style movies of people reminiscing and litigating what once was sets Mari Walker’s film at a disadvantage. But the chemistry of its stars gives the movie a curious magnetism that is almost enough to forgive its flaws.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Vivian Giang, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Five Big Questions for Elon Musk and Twitter
description: Will he go hostile, what is Twitter really worth and more.
content: Over the weekend, Twitter’s board put in place a poison pill provision in an effort to block Elon Musk, who, you might have heard, wants to buy the social media platform. The maneuver will give Twitter’s management time to assess the offer and potentially invite other buyers via a sale process.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil MacFarquhar
title: Prominent prisoners held by both sides appeal for an exchange.
description: Two British fighters held by Russian asked to be traded for Viktor Medvedchuk, a wealthy Ukrainian ally of Russia’s president, Vladimir V. Putin.
content: High-profile prisoners held by both Russia and Ukraine, including two British fighters believed captured in Mariupol, appealed on Monday to be exchanged.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: Washington Commanders Deny Financial Malfeasance in a Letter to F.T.C.
description: The N.F.L. franchise sent 102 pages of documents rebutting claims made by a former employee that the team failed to properly report ticket revenue and withheld refunds from fans.
content: The Washington Commanders on Monday offered a robust public rebuttal of congressional testimony made by a former team vice president who claimed that the team skimmed revenue from ticket sales meant to be shared with the rest of the N.F.L. and withheld security deposits from fans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Rare Culinary Tomes at the International Antiquarian Book Fair
description: The dealer Ben Kinmont’s holdings will display a collection of 50 rare wine and food books and manuscripts.
content: Ben Kinmont, a rare book dealer from Sebastopol, Calif., will be at the New York International Antiquarian Book Fair this week. Among the books he will have on display are “Ein künstlichs und nutz lichs Kochbüch” by Balthasar Staindl (1544), the fourth cookbook ever published in Germany, and “The Sesmaisons Cookery Manuscript,” in French from 1767. He also has the “Thackrey Library: An Archaeology of Pleasures,” a collection of 740 rare wine and food books and manuscripts. (Forty-six will be on display in New York.) That includes a sixth century account of the purchase of grape vines written on papyrus and books on viticulture and oenology dating from the 14th through 19th centuries. The entire Thackrey Library can be yours for $2 million.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: How a Manhunt Unfolded: An Alert, a Tweet, a Call From the Suspect
description: Frank James was on the loose for 31 hours after the subway attack.
content: Good morning. It’s Monday. We’ll look back at 31 hours when New York City was on edge — from the attack on the subway in Brooklyn to the arrest of a suspect. We’ll also see a photograph that will soon be up at the National September 11 Museum, the one image of a victim that the museum lacked.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Alex Jones’s Infowars Files for Bankruptcy
description: The conspiracy theorist and his companies are facing lawsuits over his false claims about the Sandy Hook school shooting.
content: Three companies affiliated with the far-right broadcaster and conspiracy theorist Alex Jones, among them the media outlet Infowars, filed for Chapter 11 protection on Sunday in U.S. Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District of Texas, according to court documents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Otterman
title: When Covid Enters the House, What Should We Do?
description: When someone in the family tests positive for the coronavirus, there are some guidelines to follow.
content: Though I have been writing about Covid-19 for The New York Times for the past two years, I still felt overwhelmed when my son was sent home from school sick in mid-March and tested positive. Suddenly, I was in a cluttered New York City apartment with my husband, first grader and third grader, a lot of virus particles and no clear plan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: NASCAR, ‘Survivor,’ ‘Bachelor’: All have stars in the race.
description: A handful of celebrities and star athletes are running the Boston Marathon.
content: What do a NASCAR champion, a “Survivor” and a “Bachelor” have in common? By the end of the day — if all goes well — they will all have 26.2 miles under their feet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Republicans Say, ‘Let Them Eat Hate’
description: Don’t think culture war; think pogroms.
content: So Donald Trump has endorsed J.D. Vance in the race for Ohio’s Republican Senate nomination. Will Trump’s nod tip the balance? I have no idea, and frankly I don’t care.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Corkery
title: How a Dollar General Employee Went Viral on TikTok
description: Mary Gundel loved managing a store in Tampa, Fla. But when she detailed its challenges on social media, the company — and fellow employees — took notice.
content: In January 2021, Mary Gundel received a letter from Dollar General’s corporate office congratulating her for being one of the company’s top-performing employees. In honor of her hard work and dedication, the company gave Ms. Gundel a lapel pin that read, “DG: Top 5%.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell
title: A Departing House Democrat Traces 30 Years of G.O.P. History
description: David Price sees echoes of the 1994 Republican Revolution in the 2022 midterms — and Republicans undoing the progress on voting rights that he witnessed as an aide in the 1960s.
content: As a young congressional aide, David Price witnessed the passage of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 from the Senate gallery. He remembers the dramatic moment when Senator Clair Engle of California, dying of a brain tumor and left unable to speak, was wheeled in to cast a decisive vote.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil MacFarquhar and Sophia Kishkovsky
title: Ukraine War Divides Orthodox Faithful
description: Around the world, national churches, parishes and even families are reassessing relations with Patriarch Kirill of Moscow, who has encouraged Russia’s aggression.
content: In a small parish in northern Italy affiliated with the Russian Orthodox Church, the mostly Ukrainian worshipers — IT specialists, migrant factory laborers, nurses and cleaners — decided to repudiate the full-throated support for the war in Ukraine from Patriarch Kirill of Moscow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: Four Americans Were Infected With a Virus Variant Seen in Mink
description: The cluster is the first known instance of likely animal-to-human transmission in the United States.
content: In the first year of the pandemic, at least four people in Michigan were infected with a version of the coronavirus observed mostly in mink, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention confirmed on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: A showdown in Mariupol.
content: After weeks of shelling and bombings, Russia gave Ukrainian fighters in Mariupol until yesterday morning to lay down their weapons or be “eliminated.” When Ukrainian officials vowed that they would not surrender, Russian forces intensified their attack on the southeastern city, including at the Azovstal steel plant, near Mariupol’s port. Follow the latest updates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Rikki Novetsky, Kaitlin Roberts, Mooj Zadie, Marc Georges, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
title: Biden’s Student Loan Dilemma
description: America’s two-year experiment in debt deferral has had unintended consequences.
content: Across the United States, 45 million borrowers now owe $1.6 trillion in debt for federal loans taken out for college — more than consumers owe on any other debt except mortgages.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Campbell Robertson and Jon Hurdle
title: As Philadelphia Puts On Masks Again, Other Cities Watch Closely
description: A sharp increase in new infections triggered the return of indoor mask rules a little more than a month after they were lifted.
content: PHILADELPHIA — Amid the jumble of warnings, rules and edicts on the counter of the H20 Laundromat — “No Cash,” “Watch Your Step,” “Not Responsible” — there was a new one on Monday morning, prominently displayed. “Masks required for everyone,” it said, “effective April 18.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cora Engelbrecht
title: Russian attack on Lviv shakes sense of security in a relatively safe city.
description: Vlada Belau believed she had finally established a semblance of normalcy in the city of Lviv after fleeing from Kyiv, nearly 300 miles to the east, when it was bombarded in the early days of the war.
content: Vlada Belau believed she had finally established a semblance of normalcy in the city of Lviv after fleeing from Kyiv, nearly 300 miles to the east, when it was bombarded in the early days of the war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez and Eduardo Medina
title: April Storm Brings Heavy Snow and Rain to Northeast
description: Parts of Pennsylvania received up to 8 inches of snow on Monday, forecasters said. More snowfall was expected in New York State overnight.
content: A spring storm dropped snow across central Pennsylvania and central New York State on Monday, bringing power failures and the potential for slushy roadways overnight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Fiona Mozley
title: Down on the Black Bayou, a Family History Repeats Itself
description: In “The Crocodile Bride,” Ashleigh Bell Pedersen unravels four generations of abuse and survival.
content: THE CROCODILE BRIDE By Ashleigh Bell Pedersen
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: New Rocket Fire From Gaza Follows Rising Tensions in Jerusalem
description: The first strike from Gaza in several months came just days after clashes in and around the Aqsa Mosque compound, a sacred site for both Muslims and Jews.
content: JERUSALEM — Militants in Gaza fired a rocket into Israeli airspace on Monday night that was intercepted by an Israeli air defense system, as tensions continued to rise after recent clashes between Palestinians and the Israeli police at a holy site in Jerusalem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Just in Time for Grilling Season
description: Heritage Foods now offers spicy linguiça from the sausage maker the Mayor, in Richmond, Va.
content: Heritage Foods now offers linguiça from the sausage maker the Mayor, in Richmond, Va. The signature Portuguese sausage harbors the paprika spice of chorizo but with the fire dampened, and a finer texture, but it brings on the garlic like kielbasa. It’s perfect right off the grill, or sizzled and sliced into thick coins in a mess of Little Neck clams steamed in olive oil with sweet and hot peppers. Kyle Morse, a chef who owns the Mayor, uses heritage pork shoulder for his sausage. The name linguiça derives from the Portuguese word for tongue (língua), but is thought to be a reference to only the shape.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Manuela Schär Wins Her 4th Boston Marathon in Women’s Wheelchair Race
description: She broke away from the pack early on and kept her lead for the entire race, finishing in 1 hour 41 minutes 8 seconds.
content: Manuela Schӓr of Switzerland won the Boston Marathon’s women’s wheelchair race on Monday, cruising to her fourth victory in the event.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Rules Against Air Force Officer Who Refused Vaccine
description: The justices said the Pentagon need not accommodate Lt. Col. Jonathan Dunn, who said he had a religious objection to the coronavirus vaccine.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court ruled on Monday that the Pentagon may take disciplinary action against a lieutenant colonel in the Air Force Reserve who refused to be vaccinated against the coronavirus on religious grounds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy
title: A Patriots’ Day tradition returns: a Red Sox home game.
description: Marathon runners pass Fenway Park around Mile 25.
content: In a tradition that has been on pause since the pandemic began, the Red Sox once again hosted a home game at 11 a.m. to coincide with the running of the Boston Marathon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cora Engelbrecht
title: Thousands of civilians are holed up with Ukrainian troops in Mariupol, officials say.
description: Some 2,000 civilians who were driven from their homes have sheltered in a network of tunnels beneath the plant, an aide to the city’s mayor said.
content: Intense fighting continued around a large steel factory in the southern city of Mariupol, in what appeared to be one of the last redoubts of Ukrainian forces in the besieged city, an adviser to the mayor said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Fighting for the Right to Wear Their Identity
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, April 18, 2022.
content: “What we want is to be accepted as we are, to implement these grand slogans of diversity, inclusiveness. Our only desire is to play soccer.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller
title: A Rising Tally of Lonely Deaths on the Streets
description: More than ever it has become deadly to be homeless in America, especially for men in their 50s and 60s.
content: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — Their bodies were found on public benches, lying next to bike paths, crumpled under freeway overpasses and stranded on the sun-drenched beach. Across Los Angeles County last year, the unsheltered died in record numbers, an average of five homeless deaths a day, most in plain view of the world around them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Iredale
title: They’re Some of Hollywood’s Top Publicists. Just Don’t Ask Them Why.
description: Meet the women of the Lede Company.
content: “I can’t decide what is OK and what’s not OK, you know what I mean?” Amanda Silverman said over the phone on March 1, six days into Russia’s war on Ukraine. Discussing geopolitics was not the intended purpose of the call; Ms. Silverman’s life as a celebrity publicist was. As Vladimir Putin shook the world order, she had clients to manage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: This Is Not the Year of the Optimist
description: But there’s got to be a silver lining here somewhere.
content: Bret Stephens: Happy Easter, Gail. The news has been so depressing lately. A crazy guy opens fire in a subway in Brooklyn. The Russians are committing atrocities in Ukraine and are about to start a major offensive in the east. And my tuna melt on rye costs $21 at a not-much-to-look-at New York City diner, not including the tip.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Masks Up Again in Philadelphia
description: And the end of masks on public transport?
content: Philadelphia’s newly reinstated mask mandate went into effect on Monday for all indoor public places.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Scientists Question Data Behind an Experimental Alzheimer’s Drug
description: Studies linked to Cassava Sciences, once a stock market favorite, have been retracted or challenged by medical journals.
content: A small biotech company that trumpeted an exciting new treatment for Alzheimer’s disease is now under fire for irregularities in its research results, after several studies related to its work were retracted or questioned by scientific journals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Warren
title: Elizabeth Warren: Democrats Can Avoid Disaster in November
description: More must be done to enact President Biden’s agenda before the midterm elections.
content: Democrats are the party of working people. Ahead of the 2020 election, we advanced ideas and plans that we believed would, in ways big and small, make our democracy and our economy work better for all Americans. Across this country, voters agreed with us — and gave us a majority in Washington so that we could deliver on those promises.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Citing Ukraine War, an American Resigns From Russia’s Mariinsky
description: “There’s no way I could ever be in denial of what is happening,” said the conductor Gavriel Heine, a fixture at the prestigious Russian theater.
content: The American conductor Gavriel Heine has been a fixture at the Mariinsky Theater in St. Petersburg, Russia, for 15 years. He has led hundreds of performances of classics like “Swan Lake” and “The Rite of Spring.” And he has done so as a protégé of the company’s leader: Valery Gergiev.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘White Hot’ Review: A Retailer Whose Reputation Went Down in Flames
description: This documentary, subtitled “The Rise & Fall of Abercrombie & Fitch,” is a new film that dresses up old headlines about the clothing company.
content: Pitching yesterday’s fashions as today’s news, the documentary “White Hot: The Rise & Fall of Abercrombie & Fitch” charts the onetime popularity and subsequent public disgrace of the clothing retailer, which in the 1990s positioned itself as the avatar of aspirational frattiness. In the early aughts, the brand came under fire for selling racist T-shirts and for its hiring practices. Sued for race and sex discrimination, the company settled a class-action case in 2004. In 2015, the Supreme Court revived a lawsuit against Abercrombie in another case, which involved a Muslim refused employment because she wore a head scarf.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Applications Open!
description: Submit now to the first-ever New York Times Illustration Portfolio Review.
content: We are selecting 70 illustrators to be paired with art directors from The New York Times for individual portfolio critiques. The art directors will offer feedback and guidance to further your work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Shopping for Loft Beds
description: When your ceilings are high but your square footage is limited, a loft bed may be the solution you’re after.
content: If you have a tiny bedroom that doesn’t have enough room for all the furniture you need, a loft bed may be the answer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Noble Maillard
title: A Beloved Indigenous Dessert Evolves With Each Generation
description: Different versions of grape dumplings have been passed down and adapted over time — and they are all delicious.
content: Rose Shields-Jefferson, a Chickasaw Nation elder and the firstborn of 13 children, leaned into her computer screen, her red and black beaded earrings swaying as she gave a conspiratorial smile.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: NASA Will Move Its Moon Rocket Off Launchpad for Repairs
description: Technical problems have postponed the agency’s plans for a “wet dress rehearsal,” which may further postpone the timetable for a launch.
content: NASA’s new big moon rocket is headed back to the garage for a few small repairs, possibly pushing back its maiden launch to late summer or later.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Pushing ‘Long Covid’ Sufferers Too Hard Could Cause Them to Crash
description: The employment system inadequately serves people who can work but aren’t back to 100 percent.
content: Most of us were brought up with the folk wisdom that exercise is the best medicine, and often it’s true. But not for people who are suffering from long Covid and other post-viral syndromes. For them, overexertion can severely aggravate their conditions, whose symptoms may include fatigue and brain fog. There’s even a term for it: “push and crash.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman
title: French Candidates’ Economic Programs Hold Key to the Election
description: Promising tax cuts, higher wages and changes in the retirement age, President Macron and Marine Le Pen vie for undecided voters.
content: PARIS — As President Emmanuel Macron wove through crowds during a campaign stop in northern France last week, an elderly voter got in his face to protest one of his most unpopular economic proposals: raising the retirement age to 65 from 62 to fund France’s national pension system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: How much money do the Boston Marathon champions win?
description: The Boston Marathon will give out a total of $879,500 across professional divisions on Monday.
content: Being the first to cross the finish line on Boylston Street comes with perks, not just bragging rights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: Golden State’s Playoff Reappearance Doesn’t Quite Feel Like Old Times
description: The heart of the roster — Stephen Curry, Klay Thompson and Draymond Green — is back in the N.B.A. playoffs, a world away from the team’s soul in Oakland.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — The scene felt both comfortingly familiar and oddly askew.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Meet the First Class of Our Diverse Crossword Constructor Fellowship
description: These five constructors will work for three months with New York Times puzzle editors to create grids that reflect a range of cultural reference points.
content: The New York Times Games team is pleased to announce the inaugural class for the Diverse Crossword Constructor fellowship. Selected from over 200 applicants, these five constructors will work under the guidance of the New York Times puzzle editing team for three months to create puzzles that reflect their lives and cultures. At the end of the fellowship, their puzzles will be submitted through our general process to be considered for publication.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Daniel Romanchuk of the U.S. Wins Boston Marathon Men’s Wheelchair Race
description: It was Romanchuk’s second victory in Boston. The defending champion, Marcel Hug of Switzerland, withdrew from the race on Monday morning.
content: Daniel Romanchuk of the United States won the Boston Marathon’s men’s wheelchair race on Monday, securing his second victory there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Colin
title: What if Public Funds Were Controlled by the Public?
description: Through the dry-sounding Participatory Budgeting Project, Shari Davis is pushing a quietly radical idea: Democracy shouldn’t be confined to voting.
content: Visionaries is a limited series that looks at figures who are trying to transform the way we live.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: What is Patriots’ Day?
description: The third Monday in April commemorates the Revolutionary War battles of Lexington and Concord in 1775.
content: Just as the first Tuesday in November is for voting and the second Sunday in May is for mothers, the third Monday in April holds a special place in the hearts and calendars of Massachusetts residents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: China’s Economic Trends Hint at Cost of Zero Covid Strategy
description: The country’s lockdowns have trapped truck drivers on highways, halted production lines and forced some importers to source goods from outside China.
content: BEIJING — Faced with its worst Covid-19 outbreak yet, China has been enforcing an expanding number of mass quarantines, strict lockdowns and border controls. The measures may yet work, but official data released on Monday show they are exacting a grim toll on the world’s second-largest economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $3.3 Million Homes in California
description: A 1926 Lloyd Wright showplace in Glendale, a midcentury ranch-style home in San Anselmo and a 1948 house in Orinda.
content: Lloyd Wright spent much of his early architecture career working under his father, Frank Lloyd Wright, in Southern California, where he managed the construction of the Hollyhock House (in collaboration with Rudolph Schindler) and the Ennis House, two of Los Angeles’s most architecturally significant homes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Landon Nordeman and Elizabeth Bristow
title: A Stylish Stroll at the Easter Parade
description: The bonnets are back.
content: New York City’s Easter Parade came back to life on Sunday along Fifth Avenue in Manhattan. The tradition, which began over a century and a half ago as a spontaneous stroll after holiday church services, has since evolved into a yearly fashion promenade. After a pandemic pause in 2020 and 2021, people again took to the avenue, around 53rd Street, to be seen and to see one another, doing their part to make the dark colors of winter give way with mood-lifting brights and over-the-top costumes. Bonnets and other finery were unpacked, adorned and proudly worn — not just as a fashion statement, but as a declaration of spirit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Give the Gift of Herbaceous Dark Chocolate
description: Janet Mavec, a jewelry designer inspired by her farm and gardens, now sells dark chocolate bars infused with her lemon verbena.
content: Janet Mavec, a jewelry designer whose pieces are inspired by nature, works from her Bird Haven Farm and gardens in Pottersville, N.J., where the flowers, herbs and vegetables pose for her artistry, mostly in gold-plated brass. (The farm is open to visitors on select days.) But new to her line is chocolate: She uses lemon verbena that she cultivates to infuse bars of dark chocolate with delicate, aromatic floral notes. The chocolate is 72 percent cacao from the Dominican Republic and comes wrapped in pretty, leafy paper. It’s gift-worthy for Mother’s Day (don’t give just one).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Review: ‘The Minutes,’ an Official History of American Horror
description: In Tracy Letts’s new play, a tedious City Council meeting cracks open to reveal the secret record of what happened in Big Cherry.
content: If you set out to imagine the dullest possible setting for a play, you might come up with something much like the one Tracy Letts puts before you in “The Minutes,” a Steppenwolf Theater production that opened on Sunday at Studio 54. What could be more tedious, onstage or in life, than a City Council meeting with little on the agenda besides approving the official record of the last one? Or arguing the merits of a “Lincoln Smackdown” cage match attraction at the next annual heritage festival?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Porter and Ian Willms
title: A ‘Wild West’ of Marijuana Shops Grows in Toronto
description: Permitted to operate during the pandemic, even during lockdowns, Toronto’s marijuana shops have flourished and changed the character of an iconic neighborhood.
content: TORONTO — If you are hankering for a government-sanctioned joint, then you have come to the right city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli
title: DJ Kay Slay, Fiery Radio Star and Rap Mixtape Innovator, Dies at 55
description: The one-time graffiti artist and New York D.J. for Hot 97 was known for breaking artists and stoking beefs that gave fuel to the careers of Nas, Jay-Z, 50 Cent and more.
content: DJ Kay Slay, who served as a crucial bridge between hip-hop generations, developing from a teenage B-boy and graffiti writer into an innovative New York radio personality known for his pugnacious mixtapes that stoked rap beefs, broke artists and helped change the music business, died on Sunday in New York. He was 55.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: The Supreme of Baby Clothes
description: Ruffled onesies. Tiny cardigans. An online shopping mania has emerged for the brand Kate Quinn.
content: People who work at Kate Quinn, a fashion brand that specializes in clothes for children and babies, say they feel like hiding under their desks whenever a new collection goes on sale.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: If Two Songs Sound Alike, Is It Stealing?
description: A judge ruled that Ed Sheeran did not plagiarize “Shape of You.” In pop music, are coincidences bound to happen?
content: When songs have similar melodies, chords or lyrics, do you think it is more often a result of plagiarism or sheer coincidence?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and John Ismay
title: To Push Back Russians, Ukrainians Hit a Village With Cluster Munitions
description: The New York Times verified that Ukraine’s forces appeared to fire at least two of these internationally banned weapons in a neighborhood, putting Ukrainian civilians at extreme risk.
content: HUSARIVKA, Ukraine — It was in early March when the spent warhead of a cluster munition rocket landed next to Yurii Doroshenko’s home in eastern Ukraine, having dispensed its lethal bomblets over his village.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Man Charged in Fatal Stabbing of California High School Student
description: Anthony Gray, 52, was charged with murder after the attack on a 15-year-old girl outside Stagg High School in Stockton, Calif.
content: A 52-year-old man was charged with murder after a 15-year-old girl was stabbed to death outside her high school in central California on Monday morning, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: The Return of the White House Easter Egg Roll
description: President Biden and Jill Biden, the first lady, hosted the first Egg Roll since the beginning of the pandemic. It was the largest event held at the White House since they moved in.
content: WASHINGTON — The last time the White House held an Easter Egg Roll, the president ditched the Easter bunny and briefed a child on his border wall. Phrases like “masking ordinance” and “rapid testing” were not yet part of the national lexicon. A Corona was just a beer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Gonzalez
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Better Call Saul’ and a Freddie Mercury Tribute
description: AMC’s “Breaking Bad” prequel begins its final season. And a documentary about a 1992 tribute concert for Freddie Mercury airs on the CW.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, April 18-24. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: California Delays K-12 Vaccine Mandate
description: State officials say schoolchildren won’t have to be vaccinated against the coronavirus until July 2023 at the earliest, a year later than planned.
content: In October, Gov. Gavin Newsom announced that California would become the first state to require all schoolchildren to receive the coronavirus vaccine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brett Anderson
title: They Fled Afghanistan for America. Now They Feed the Newest Arrivals.
description: In Virginia, Maryland and Washington, D.C., established Afghan restaurateurs are reaching out to help refugees fleeing the return of the Taliban.
content: RICHMOND, Va. — Hamidullah Noori was 8 years old when his father, uncle and cousin were killed by Taliban militants in Kabul, Afghanistan. As the eldest son, he soon went to work to support his family, selling boiled potatoes and balloons from a pushcart. Violence and flight have shaped his life ever since.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: The big questions about what happens next in Elon Musk’s bid for Twitter.
description: After Twitter’s board put in place a poison pill provision, Elon Musk appears to be hinting at the possibility of a hostile bid.
content: Over the holiday weekend, Twitter’s board put in place a poison pill provision in an effort to block Elon Musk, who wants to buy the social media platform. The maneuver, which would make it more difficult and expensive for Mr. Musk to acquire shares without the approval of the board, will give Twitter’s management time to assess the offer and potentially invite other buyers via a sale process.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘Sway'
title: Tony Kushner on the Republican ‘Fantasy’ of a Nation Controlled by ‘Straight White Men’
description: The playwright discusses the recent wave of anti-L.G.B.T.Q. policies and how far the country has — or hasn’t — come since the AIDS epidemic.
content: From Gov. Ron DeSantis signing Florida’s so-called Don’t Say Gay bill to Gov. Greg Abbott issuing a Texas directive that would classify medical care for transgender adolescents as “child abuse,” Republicans across the country seem to be doubling down on anti-L.G.B.T.Q. policies. Their argument? It’s about “parental rights.” But the playwright Tony Kushner has seen this kind of battle play out before. His “Angels in America” hit two-part play examined the AIDS epidemic and L.G.B.T.Q. life in the United States. And Kushner says this new wave of legislation is just the latest incarnation of a clampdown on rights under the conservative “fantasy” of a nation under “exclusive control by white straight men.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Arraf, Ivan Nechepurenko and Mark Landler
title: Ukraine Says Russia Begins Assault in the East After Raining Missiles Nationwide
description: The president of Ukraine and a top national security aide said the Russian offensive, anticipated for weeks, had finally begun after a Russian missile barrage that included the first deadly strike on the western city of Lviv.
content: LVIV, Ukraine — Ukraine said Monday that Russian forces had launched a ground assault along a nearly 300-mile front in the east after hitting the country with one of the most intense missile barrages in weeks, including the first lethal strike on Lviv, the western city that has been a refuge for tens of thousands of fleeing civilians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: Apollo is said to be considering participating in a bid for Twitter.
description: Investors have been skeptical that Elon Musk would be able to cobble together the funds needed to buy Twitter.
content: The private equity firm Apollo Global Management is considering participating in a bid for Twitter by offering debt financing to potential buyers, including the Tesla chief executive Elon Musk, according to a person with knowledge of the situation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danya Issawi
title: The Lingerie Addict Says Goodbye
description: Since 2008, the blog has explored the ins and outs of intimate apparel with a fervor that has earned its creator, Cora Harrington, a considerable following.
content: The Lingerie Addict, a blog where for more than 14 years unmentionables were not only mentioned, but also the subject of thoughtful consideration, announced on Sunday that it was ending publication.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo and Robin Pogrebin
title: Rushing Against War, and Time, Ukraine Makes It to the Biennale
description: Russia’s invasion complicated well-laid plans. But, despite the odds, Ukraine will present work at the international art showcase in Venice.
content: VENICE — The 78 bronze funnels were ready, the pump tested and the backdrop was almost done. So when it looked as if war was most likely coming to Ukraine, Maria Lanko, one of the curators of the Ukrainian pavilion at the Venice Biennale, was determined to get the artist Pavlo Makov’s fountain sculpture safely out of the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson and Adam Satariano
title: The Next Hurdle in Europe’s Energy Transition: Being More Enticing Than NFTs
description: Financing the next generation of green energy technologies means larger investments and getting venture capitalists to turn their attention away from “fast money.”
content: LONDON — When Jakob Bitner was 7, he left Russia for Germany with his parents and sister. Twenty-eight years later, he is set on solving a vexing green-energy problem that could help Germany end its dependence on imported energy from Russia, or anywhere.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Bottled Cocktails, Ready to Pour, From William Grant & Sons
description: The Scottish distilling company uses top-shelf spirits for drinks like Scotch-based riffs on the manhattan and the old fashioned.
content: William Grant & Sons, the Scottish distilling company, has a portfolio of brands like Hendrick’s Gin, Reyka Vodka, Glenfiddich and Monkey Shoulder Scotch. Now the company has come up with Batch & Bottle: ready-made cocktails in bottles, not cans, using top-shelf spirits. They’re neither gimmicky nor sweet, but straightforward classics like a martini and a cosmopolitan with a whisper of rhubarb. There is also a Scotch-based old fashioned and manhattan, for a different riff on tradition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sungjoo Yoon
title: I’m a High School Junior. Let’s Talk About ‘Huckleberry Finn’ and ‘Mockingbird.’
description: The problem isn’t that we disagree; it’s how we argue.
content: BURBANK, Calif. — In late 2020, when the Burbank Unified School District removed five classic novels from mandatory reading lists in my city’s classrooms, I started a petition to protest the decision. The petition, which is still open, has more than 5,000 signatures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Allen
title: Harrison Birtwistle, Fiercely Modernist Composer, Dies at 87
description: His labyrinthine, theatrical works placed him in the first rank of 20th-century English composers, though his music was often tagged as “difficult.”
content: Harrison Birtwistle, whose intensely theatrical compositions and uncompromising modernism made him the most prominent British composer since Benjamin Britten, died on Monday at his home in Mere, England. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: F.D.A. Investigating Reports of Illness From Lucky Charms
description: Thousands of consumers complained of gastrointestinal issues after eating the cereal, but General Mills said it had not found evidence of a link.
content: The Food and Drug Administration said on Monday that it was looking into reports that thousands of people had become ill after eating Lucky Charms, the frosted toasted oat cereal with marshmallows marketed as “magically delicious.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Treasury makes a plea for more I.R.S. funding on Tax Day.
description: The Biden administration continued to push for $80 billion in new funding for the tax collection agency.
content: WASHINGTON — As millions of Americans raced to finish filing their tax returns on Monday, the Biden administration made another plea for Congress to give the Internal Revenue Service more money.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Jackson
title: When the World Is at the Whim of One Billionaire
description: How Elon Musk is asserting his influence through stakeholder capitalism.
content: From “The Daily” newsletter: One big idea on the news, from the team that brings you “The Daily” podcast. You can sign up for the newsletter here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Caspian Kang
title: How the Elites Monopolize Empathy
description: There are problems with how inequality gets discussed. That doesn’t mean we should stop talking about it.
content: A couple of weeks ago, I wrote about Mackenzie Fierceton, a former student at the University of Pennsylvania, who was accused by the school of misrepresenting herself as a first-generation college student. Penn seemed not to believe her claims of abuse despite the fact that she had been placed in foster care (the reason she considered herself first-generation). Like other elite institutions, Penn seemed to be using what I called a “trauma algorithm” to determine which hardships counted and which ones should be investigated. That newsletter, which was based on an article the journalist Rachel Aviv wrote in The New Yorker, generated a great deal of response from you, the readers, so I want to return to the subject.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland and Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: A second global Covid-19 summit led by the White House is set for May.
description: Efforts to subsidize more global vaccinations have stalled in Congress, and new coronavirus cases are on the rise in the U.S.
content: The White House announced on Monday that it would co-host the second global Covid-19 summit next month, a gathering intended to build momentum for vaccine donations and for ending what the White House called the “acute phase” of the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: Don’t Call Her ‘Baby.’ At 62, Jennifer Grey is Taking the Lead.
description: In her memoir, “Out of the Corner,” the “Dirty Dancing” star opens up about rhinoplasty gone wrong, the implosion of her career and why she’s telling her story now.
content: Jennifer Grey arrived at a recent breakfast at the Peninsula Hotel in Beverly Hills in a flurry of regrets about the state of her shirt and her hair (both were impeccable). Before the waiter had a chance to pour coffee, the star of “Dirty Dancing” asked a question that would be an apt subtitle for her memoir, “Out of the Corner,” which Ballantine will publish on May 3.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: For Those With Style and a Love of Foraging
description: The scarf company Echo has reissued several old designs, including one of mushrooms on a 35-inch silk square.
content: Echo, a New York company that has been producing scarves and similar accessories for nearly 100 years, has plumbed its archives and reissued several designs of yore. Mushrooms richly border one of them, on a 35-inch silk square that’s worth considering for Mother’s Day for a food-loving or foraging recipient. It comes in a purple-brown they call port, or in black.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage and Heather Murphy
title: Federal Judge Strikes Down Mask Mandate for Planes and Public Transit
description: The nation’s largest airlines dropped the requirement within hours of the ruling, but New York’s M.T.A. said its passengers must still wear a mask for now.
content: WASHINGTON — A federal judge in Florida struck down the  mask requirement on airplanes, trains, buses and other public transportation on Monday, less than a week after the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention had extended it through May 3.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: Sadness and Loss Are Everywhere. Books Can Help.
description: The saddest stories can show us how full of grace the fallen world can be.
content: NASHVILLE — I was 10 when “Brian’s Song” aired in 1971 as an ABC Movie of the Week. It is the story of the abiding friendship that grew as Brian Piccolo, who was white, and Gale Sayers, who was Black, competed for playing time as N.F.L. rookies with the Chicago Bears. It’s also the story of Piccolo’s death of cancer at 26. I was a girl in Birmingham, Ala., then “the most segregated city in America,” when “Brian’s Song” reminded this country that race was not an insurmountable barrier to love.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: The Battle for the Donbas
description: Russia’s offensive in eastern Ukraine has begun, Ukraine says.
content: Good evening. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: Jim Farley Tries to Reinvent Ford and Catch Up to Elon Musk and Tesla
description: Ford’s chief executive is about to introduce an electric F-150 pickup truck that could determine whether the automaker can survive and thrive in an industry dominated by Tesla.
content: On a recent Tuesday afternoon, Jim Farley, the chief executive of Ford Motor, took a spin in what could become one of the most important vehicles in the company’s 118-year history: an electric F-150 pickup truck.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mara Altman
title: The Pandemic Has Been Hard on Our Feet
description: Here’s what’s plaguing them and how to avoid it.
content: In March of 2020, Krista Fahs began working from home. As she sidled up to her desk, the 53-year-old sales associate for a computer distributor put aside her usual sneakers. She found herself doing laundry, playing with her cat and even visiting neighbors without putting on shoes. “I was barefoot all the time,” she said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski and Patricia Cohen
title: Bleak assessments of the Russian economy clash with Putin’s rosy claims.
description: While Vladimir Putin boasts that Russia is holding up under Western sanctions, his central bank chief and the mayor of Moscow warned that the worst was yet to come.
content: Russia’s central bank chief warned on Monday that the consequences of Western sanctions were only beginning to be felt, and Moscow’s mayor said that 200,000 jobs were at risk in the Russian capital alone, stark acknowledgments that undermined President Vladimir V. Putin’s contention that sanctions had failed to destabilize the Russian economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Haramis
title: Searching for the Notorious Celebrity Book Stylist
description: In the name of personal branding, influencers might be paying someone to make them look like readers. But does a novel deserve more respect than a handbag?
content: YIGIT TURHAN, THE Milan-based director of branding and entertainment relations at Valentino, was in Los Angeles last year when he first heard about the infamous book stylist. Rumor had it that celebrities and fashion influencers were paying someone to select reading material for them to carry in public. (Whether they read it was another thing, and, to echo a sentiment shared by a pair of withering college-student characters on the HBO satire “The White Lotus” (2021), beside the point.) In paparazzi photos or on their own social media accounts, these props, because that’s essentially what they were, communicated something far more powerful than a press statement ever could. Today, when entertainers are required to have an immediate, uncontroversial and neatly packaged response to every newsworthy occurrence — when their personal brand is expected to, as Walt Whitman once wrote, contain multitudes — a picture of a book is worth a thousand words. But when Turhan, 34, asked for the name of this mysterious figure, his contacts got cagey. “They acted like they had never heard of such a thing, as if we hadn’t just discussed it,” he recalls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Lil Durk and Morgan Wallen Return to the Top of the Album Chart
description: The country star’s “Dangerous: The Double Album” has had tremendous staying power, landing at No. 2 in its 66th week out.
content: The Chicago rap mainstay Lil Durk returns to No. 1 on the Billboard album chart, with his latest LP, “7220,” beating out new releases by Jack White and Fivio Foreign after its debut a month ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anushka Patil
title: Calls for Covid funding are renewed as doses near expiration.
description: A tense battle may soon resume over the stalled $10 billion pandemic aid package that senators failed to pass earlier this month.
content: Millions of coronavirus vaccine doses that the United States has already purchased and could send abroad could soon expire because of the impasse in Congress over additional pandemic aid, Senator Chris Coons has warned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Strauss
title: Before Brunch, a Stop at the Altar
description: Facing a shortage of prime times, more couples are marrying earlier in the day at weddings that some are finding easier to book and less expensive to host.
content: On Saturday March 12, Bria Pugh found herself wide-awake at 4 a.m. She isn’t an early-riser, nor did she have pre-wedding jitters. This was the call time for her hair and makeup before she walked down the aisle to marry Matthew Norman six hours later.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: venturesome
description: This word has appeared in eight articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word venturesome has appeared in eight articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on May 28 in “A Spiritual Meeting in the Sand and a Wedding There, Too” by Lois Smith Brady:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Peres Jepchirchir Wins the Boston Marathon in a Thrilling Finish
description: Jepchirchir, the Olympic and New York City champion, surged past Ababel Yeshaneh in the last few moments to win by four seconds.
content: It was a marathon, but it ended in a sprint.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Prasad Philbrick
title: The ‘Messy Middle’
description: The West is arming Ukraine and punishing Russia. Today we look at the countries that aren’t.
content: If you live in most any Western country, your government’s support for Ukraine, including sending weapons and imposing sanctions on Russia, can give the impression of a united global response to Vladimir Putin’s invasion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Evans Chebet of Kenya Wins Boston Men’s Race, His First Major Marathon Victory
description: Chebet stamped himself as a major marathoning force with a decisive victory in 2 hours 6 minutes 51 seconds.
content: Evans Chebet of Kenya stamped himself as a major marathoning force with a decisive victory in 2 hours 6 minutes 51 seconds in the men’s race in Boston on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: After a 2-Year Ban, Hugs Are Back at Disneyland
description: Guests no longer have to stay away from Mickey. “That personal, one-on-one interaction may be the most powerful offering that the Walt Disney Company has.”
content: ANAHEIM, Calif. — As the smell of cinnamon rolls and suntan lotion wafted through the spring air at Disneyland on Monday morning, Rory Sutherland flung herself on the sidewalk and had what can only be described as a hissy fit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Rejects Case on Juror Said to Harbor Racial Bias
description: The court’s three liberal members dissented, saying that Kristopher Love, a Texas death row inmate, should have been allowed to pursue his claim.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday turned away an appeal from a death row inmate in Texas who said his jury had been tainted by racial bias. The inmate, Kristopher Love, a Black man, had objected to the seating of a juror who had said he believed “nonwhite races” to be the “more violent races.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: April 18, 2022
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, April 18, 2022.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: The World Bank slashes its forecast for global economic growth.
description: The bank now expects the global economy to grow at a rate of 3.2 percent in 2022, down from its previous estimate of 4.1 percent.
content: The World Bank is slashing its forecast for global economic growth this year, citing the war in Ukraine, inflation and the lingering effects of the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: The men’s defending wheelchair champion withdraws less than an hour before the race.
description: Marcel Hug of Switzerland decided not to compete in the Boston Marathon for medical reasons.
content: Marcel Hug of Switzerland, the defending men’s wheelchair champion, withdrew less than an hour before the start of the race, citing medical reasons, the Boston Athletic Association said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tejal Rao
title: In West Oakland, Barbecue Is Back — With a Side of Fried Chicken
description: With Horn Barbecue and Kowbird fried chicken, the chef Matt Horn calls back to the neighborhood’s roots while bringing his own style to the pit.
content: OAKLAND, Calif. — If you’re in this jumbled, chatty line, enveloped in the music and wood smoke by Mandela Parkway, you’re waiting for Matt Horn’s barbecue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Can the S.E.C. Require ‘Gag Orders’ When It Settles Cases?
description: The Supreme Court has been asked to review the practice, which a judge called “a stew of confusion and hypocrisy” and which challengers say violates the First Amendment.
content: WASHINGTON — In the summer of 2020, as the pandemic raged and the presidential election neared, Michael D. Cohen, President Donald J. Trump’s onetime lawyer and fixer, was put to a choice. Mr. Cohen wanted to serve out the balance of his three-year sentence, for campaign finance violations and other crimes, at home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: ‘Let’s Not Do That Again,’ a Crackling Satire Set Against a Senate Run
description: Grant Ginder’s fifth novel is about a woman whose adult children alternately help and threaten her political aspirations.
content: The novelist Grant Ginder is blessed with a byline so strong that it sounds like a nom de plume. For over a decade he’s also given great title: “This Is How It Starts” (2009). “The People We Hate at the Wedding” (2017). “Honestly, We Meant Well” (2019). This is the guy I want to sit next to at the wedding.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman, Alexandra Berzon and Michael S. Schmidt
title: Trump Allies Continue Legal Drive to Erase His Loss, Stoking Election Doubts
description: Fifteen months after they tried and failed to overturn the 2020 election, the same group of lawyers and associates is continuing efforts to “decertify” the vote, feeding a false narrative.
content: A group of President Donald J. Trump’s allies and associates spent months trying to overturn the 2020 election based on his lie that he was the true winner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steph Cha
title: Down the Rabbit Hole
description: Debut novels follow Asian American women researching the lives and work of elusive artists.
content: As every writer, teacher and tyrant knows, art is a powerful thing. These two debut novels explore the danger and wonder of art, its capacity to distort and illuminate the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Verleger and David G. Victor
title: Why It’s Time to Start Caring Much More About Clean Hydrogen
description: Europe is giving investors the green light they need to take risks on climate technologies.
content: Today’s energy crisis has a familiar ring. In the wake of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, energy supplies have faltered and prices have skyrocketed. Americans are seeing costly gasoline, and in Europe, natural gas prices are around five times typical levels for this time of year, driving up the price of electricity and even threatening bankruptcies across industries that depend on gas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Felice Belman
title: What to Know About Patriots’ Day
description: Celebrating the earliest battles of the Revolutionary War is a traditional rite of spring in New England.
content: Celebrating the earliest battles of the Revolutionary War is a traditional rite of spring in New England.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Illustrations By Agnes Lee
title: A Late Night Subway Session
description: A surprise performance underground, from this week's Metropolitan Diary
content: A surprise performance underground, from this week's Metropolitan Diary
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Marchese
title: Julia Roberts Hasn’t Changed. But Hollywood Has.
description: “There were incremental shifts in opportunity and it made more sense. Now it’s made more of air.”
content: “There were incremental shifts in opportunity and it made more sense. Now it’s made more of air.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: When – and Why – to Still Wear a Mask
description: Experts weigh in on what you need to know.
content: Experts weigh in on what you need to know.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What You Get for $3.3 Million in California
description: A 1926 Lloyd Wright showplace in Glendale, a midcentury ranch-style home in San Anselmo and a 1948 house in Orinda.
content: A 1926 Lloyd Wright showplace in Glendale, a midcentury ranch-style home in San Anselmo and a 1948 house in Orinda.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Smokers Welcome
description: Matt Horn expands beyond his popular barbecue restaurant with a new chicken business in West Oakland, Calif.
content: Matt Horn expands beyond his popular barbecue restaurant with a new chicken business in West Oakland, Calif.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Bidens Host Their First Easter Egg Roll
description: President Biden and the first lady, Jill Biden, hosted the first Easter Egg Roll at the White House since the beginning of the coronavirus pandemic.
content: President Biden and the first lady, Jill Biden, hosted the first Easter Egg Roll at the White House since the beginning of the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook Right Now
description: It’s teatime: Make Eric Kim’s chamomile cake with strawberry icing for your next afternoon break.
content: Good morning. Eric Kim’s latest “Eat” column in The New York Times Magazine takes on the pleasures of afternoon tea. He doesn’t approach the ritual in the British sense, nor in a ceremonial one. A friend bangs through the door and he brews a pot of chamomile or burdock, then serves it over conversation, ideally with a slice of cake: “a perfectly contained moment, a pause from the outside world.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Attention, High Schoolers: We Want to Hear From You
description: We’d like to know your opinion. Send us a letter about a recent article that caught your eye in The Times.
content: Once again we invite high school students to enter our letter-writing competition. Write a letter to the editor in response to a Times news or opinion article from the past week, and we will choose some of our favorites for publication.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Elon Musk’s Bid to Take Over Twitter
description: Readers discuss the free speech and media ownership issues raised by the offer. Also: Strategy in Ukraine; Bernie Sanders; preying on people of color.
